One thing I need to add ... I  did not specify in the spec, but certainly a thing you need to consider in your design is the input format of each operation. Think about what your 'message' would look like in each operation, remembering that HTTP has URL parameters as well as request body and headers.It is generally considered that 'clean' API interface will pass JSON or XML representations in the HTTP message body (as opposed to passing everything in the URL parameters). You should certainly think about this in the implementation.

Hi, in the test cases:Case 3: Multiple OrderCashier creates an order (order 1)Cashier creates an order (order 2)Cashier creates an order (order 3)Cashier amends the Order‐2 by adding an additionCashier creates a Payment for the order‐1Cashier creates a Payment for the order‐2Barista gets the list of all Open Orders (two orders are available)What does open order mean? In case 3 only 2 orders are open orders, so does it mean orders that are paid? Or orders that are paid but are not yet processed (drink is not made yet)?The document says \'The detail of multiple orders can be retreived anytime by status. The response of this must contain the list of all orders matching the status given.\' Does this mean the open orders? Should we write other APIs that retrieve a list of order by status (such as paid but not processed, or processed but not paid, or not paid and not processed, or paid and processed)?I think it makes sense that the barista would like to check which orders are not yet processed to avoid making drinks for the same order repeatedly. This is the only scene I can think about in which someone would like to get orders by status. The cashier would only check processing status and payment status (for a particular order, not all orders in some status) when amending or cancelling an order, and the barista would only check payment status (for a particular order, not all orders in some status) before releasing the drink for the order. So why are there only two orders available as open orders in case 3? Does the barista only process orders that are paid? But in that case it will make no sense for the cashier to check the processing status when updating an order since just checking payment status will do.Thank you!

So according to this, the test case 3 should have three 'open orders' instead of two. There is a bit of confusion about what an 'open' order is.I'd say think about the workflow presented in the spec and see what kind of state flags are necessary to service the scenarios.An order can be placed (open)An order can be made (you can pick a name of the status here, but this is basically to flag that the barista has picked up the order)An order can be paid (this can happen independently of the barista picking up the order). Maybe you just need a separate way of checking this then? Think about this.An order can be cancelled (I told you under what condition this could happen)An order can be released (this status is decided by the barista, and will be allowed only after payment is checked)For 'released orders' to be 'deleted' from the list is fine. But of course, this doesn't mean it is deleted from the resources collection.Maybe I can further clarify about the workflows depicted in the spec:The main point here is the coffee order resource is being ‘worked on’ by two processes and each process can individually update an order (the same order). The API design should be aware of the possibility that, barista can pick up an order, and the payment can be made by the customer. These two can happen independently of each other.I think the confusion was in the assumption that the order and payment have to happen first.
